Sustainability

It’s Been 20 Years Since Miguel Adrover Disrupted NYFW—Here Are All the Ways He Was Ahead of His Time

By Laird Borrelli-Persson
September 4, 2019

Miguel Adrover, the Spanish designer who shot like a glistening comet through the New York fashion scene in the aughts, was—and remains—unfiltered. He speaks his mind, and he follows his passions. One of those is saving the environment. By inclination and necessity, Adrover was thinking green 20 years ago. In 2007, he reportedly turned down a job with a major label to work with the eco-conscious German company, Hessnatur. Now, having returned to his native Majorca, the designer is creating art using pieces from his fashion archives. In fact, he’s recently become involved with Extinction Rebellion and is working to establish a base for the movement on the Balearic island.

From a distance of 20 years, the self-trained Adrover also seems clairvoyant. Certainly, he can lay claim to some fashion “firsts.” He ventures that he’s probably the first designer to drop out of school at 12 (to work on the family farm) and to receive a Perry Ellis Award while living in a rat-infested basement. Adrover describes himself as an underdog and a champion of underdogs; certainly, he’s an embodiment of the New York version of the American Dream. “It was my city; it was where people accepted me, where I could raise my voice and all that stuff,” he says. He lived and worked downtown, where he also co-ran Horn, a boutique for avant-garde designers.

Adrover’s first collection, presented in 1999, had all the grit and rawness associated with downtown, and it immediately established him as a designer to watch. The stand-out piece? A tattered “I Love New York” T-shirt with ruffled sleeves.

Even if his second collection, for Fall 2000, had been his last, Adrover would still merit a page in fashion history. The show opened with a repurposed coat dress made from a Burberry raincoat turned inside-out and worn backward. It was shocking, beautiful, and somehow pure—and it was copyright infringement. He was sued. Also in that collection was a coat made of mattress ticking that came not from a store but from a mattress Adrover found on the street and dragged to his studio upon learning it had belonged to the English-born actor and man-about-downtown, Quentin Crisp. These were clothes that were resourceful, inventive, and emotional, and despite Adrover’s own bohemianism, rather classical. They attracted the attention of a backer, Pegasus. It was a deal that quickly soured.

Adrover was a master tailor, but his range was wide, stretching from streetwear to one-of-a-kind marvels. A pair of shows, for Fall 2001 and Spring 2002, were inspired by Egypt, where Adrover worked and lived for a while. From 2002 to 2005 the designer showed fall and spring clothes in one collection, a move that was green but also complimented his way of working. Unable to finance his company after his Spring 2005 show—he took a bow wearing a T-shirt that read, “Anyone see a backer?”—he opted out of high fashion for a bit, but he struck New York Fashion Week like lightning once more, for Fall 2012. Despite its aggressive f-you’s, this collection was a radical proposal of hand-assembled repurposed clothes, which retain relevance today.

“A lot of things I did before, they are actually happening now,” Adrover noted recently on a phone call from his hometown. It’s true—the fashion system is finally catching up with Adrover’s innovations, some of which date back 20 years. Here, the designer elaborates on some of them.

Diversity and Inclusion

  • Adrover’s castings included friends and family, and models young and old, of all sizes, and all ethnicities back when diversity and inclusion were not common on the catwalk.*

I think I was the first designer to kind of like adore the underdog—and I represent the underdog. For me, it was really important to bring up people that had never been represented before on a catwalk. Our casting was trying to represent all kinds of social classes, [sort of] like what you see when you go to the subway. You see an executive man from Wall Street, and you see like a homeless person…. I tried to introduce, you know, like different types: different ages and social classes, different ethnicities—everything. [That’s] what New York is, right?

My range was touching all corners of society. It was for the rapper; it was for the lady uptown. It was for the working people in midtown, and it was, like, for the crazy people from the East Village. New York has the multicultural thing, and I think it had never been expressed before on the catwalks in New York, or in Europe, either. We [did castings] in the subways and on the streets. Also, of course, through agencies. We always had girls get really involved with all the energy and all the philosophy that was behind the presentation. It was just opening [up to] new cultures, you know, but Americans love to see themselves everywhere. Sometimes you need to open the eyes to other things, you know?

Repurposing

The most important thing that I think I’ve done is repurposing. The whole [push] behind that was like—I remember when my granddad passed away, the clothes he had, they meant so much for me and for my mom and my dad. I really didn’t want to throw them away. It’s great when you have pieces that have a sentiment, like an emotion, [that isn’t] just coming from a straight piece of new fabric that you just buy. You could be wearing something that belonged to your grandmom. I mean that was the whole point, you know, behind all this.

The Burberry coat had belonged to a friend of mine, Peter Hidalgo. He’s a designer too, and a great illustrator; really one of my best friends in New York. And he worked for me, but before he was working for me, one night I went to his house, and it was a party, and he got the raincoat, and we started vogueing, and I put it that way. And I say to him, ‘Oh my God, I really need to use that for the show,’ and he gave it to me. I brought it to the studio and it ended up being like that, inside-out and backward. I didn’t really unsew anything. It was the same [as it was; I just gave it] a new reinterpretation, you know, a new life.

Emotion

For us, it was really important also somehow to ... I would I say, feel the clothes. One of the things that was [important] in my work [is that] my clothes have a soul, a soul inside. Because [some of them] were made from material that belonged to people, they mean so much—like, you know, the mattress Quentin Crisp slept on his whole life. When you touch with your hands [this kind of emotional clothing], it [feels] different than when it comes from a factory.

Local Production

We produced in New York. My tailoring [was done by] Martin Greenfield—the best tailor in New York—[who is] based in Brooklyn. We’d also do a lot of the stuff in the studio because it was handmade. There were couture [pieces] in the collections. Remember the shirts with the New York Yankees baseball caps on the shoulders? We bought almost 200 [caps], you know, and we did those in the studio. When I signed the contract with Pegasus [in 2000], we built this big studio on the Bowery, and we had all the equipment there, all the machines; we had like a full floor for sample making, [so] it was easy to produce these one-of-a-kind pieces, or very small productions too. But of course, when you get big sales all over, you can’t really control that anymore. You know, for me, I always feel that we went too quick, too fast, too big. That’s the American mentality, isn’t it? It was kind of like the American dream.

Combining Seasons

I was already talking about climate change, and also, for me [showing more than once a year] was not making that much sense. You know, most of the time when it was hot in New York, the people that could afford my clothes went to places that were cold; and when it was winter, they’d go to places that were hot, [so I thought], if my clients do all this traveling to avoid the climate, why don’t we do one collection a year? [That also worked] because of the way my presentations were. They were not only based on clothing and on the sales; I had a story to tell. There were all these characters; they needed to be developed. It wasn’t [just about] going to see a show; somehow, [the presentation] was a little bit like a barometer about society. Most of the time, what I tried to do was to represent the moment that we live in, you know what I mean? Not going to old movies or to Hollywood. My studies were much more geopolitical. I would say a lot [about] social and environmental consciousness. And I thought, once a year was much more than enough; and also, after that was production. For me, I love production, but separate from the other stuff. The two things together, I think they’re really not working together too well.

Pro-Women

I [showed] the woman taking all positions in society, even the men’s ones. If you look at all my early shows, you will see men’s sartoriali [tailoring]. It’s done by hand with horsehair and canvas inside and everything. [We used all] the techniques [used for menswear]. I used a lot of girls that had really strong images, androgynous looks that represent the man—but it was her. Nobody picked up on that.

Circularity

The last collection that I did in New York, Out of My Mind, I thought was a totally new way of seeing clothing. It was totally like a new beginning for me, [a way] to see clothes in a totally different way. I remember showing a preview [of that collection] to Harold Koda from the Metropolitan. He said [something like], “We don’t have a name for that. This is repurposing that never has been done before. It’s like you taking something for another label, and you reinterpreted it a totally different way, but without unsewing.”

I didn’t use any fabric machines, any patterns—any of that—everything was done by hand. It was all like garments made from things from my grandma, you know, sheets from my bed, towels from McDonald’s. [Even the way] to sell the collection was planned, and I really did [go through with it] with seven clients here in Majorca. I asked them to look in their own closets and put all the garments that they liked on a rack and tell me what look they liked, and I made it out of their own clothes from their own closets. I would go to their house, and I would say, “for this, I need a blazer, and I need like a long coat or [whatever] to create these,” you know what I mean? I do collage, and these kinds of pieces have more connection, more emotion. It was a totally new way also of reutilization of the clothes; this way you don’t contaminate anything. Also, this way [of designing] always [produces] something out of the blue, [beyond] expectation. [From there], always comes something new.

Political Engagement

It was all political. All my shows, they were political because politics is what we’re living every day. That’s what really affects our lives. There’s nothing more exciting, nothing more creative than that. I don’t need to escape, you know, into a dreamy, world of like the ’70s or the ’60s or whatever. I think today we have so much on our hands to get creative and to get excited about, even to get angry [about], and [the opportunity] to say what you believe in. Fashion is so powerful. Clothing is so powerful. It’s a shame [when] you go to these shows, and you don’t feel anything after that. What, a beautiful dress? Oh my God, how many beautiful dresses can we see? It’s thousands, thousands, thousands. It doesn’t change anything. Politics has always been my big motive, and I get moved by that.

This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

Christian Lacroix is Laird Borrelli-Persson’s fashion raison d’etre; the way he combined romance and historicism set her on the path she is following today. Borrelli-Persson studied literature at Boston College, spending her junior year abroad at Oxford, where she added some art history.
